title: How to Use Tree Diagrams
text: When looking at a tree diagram, it consists of "branches", sometimes labeled with frequencies (whole numbers) or probabilities (fractions). Each branch of the tree represents a "choice" of sorts and each level represents the completion of a choice, and at the bottom of the tree--the leaf--houses the final outcomes. To get to the final outcome, you want to multiply all the probabilities going down the tree from the top to the end of the leaf.

title: Using the Tree Diagram
text: We want to calculate the probability of choosing two kittens of the same coolor, meaning P(TT OR BB). Let's start with P(TT). This mean we need to pick a tabby kitten first. What is P(T)?

title: Using the Tree Diagram
text: We want to calculate P(TT) first. That means the second kitten is tabby. After traversing down the tabby column for the first kitten, what's the probability that the second kitten is tabby? In effect, what is P(T|T)?

title: Calculating Probability
text: Now, multiply the two probabilities, $$P\left(T\right) P\left(T|T\right)=P(TT)$$. What is the answer?

title: Using the Tree Diagram
text: We want to calculate P(BB) second. That means the first kitten is B. What is P(B)?

title: Using the Tree Diagram
text: We want to calculate P(BB) second. That means the second kitten is B. After traversing down the black column for the first kitten, what's the probability that the second kitten is black? In effect, what is P(B|B)?

title: Calculating Probability
text: Now, multiply the two probabilities, $$P\left(B\right) P\left(B|B\right)=P(BB)$$. What is the answer?

title: Summing the Probabilities
text: Since we want to find P(TT OR BB), we use the operator, which means we add up the two probabilities. What is P(TT OR $$BB)=P\left(TT\right)+P\left(BB\right)=P(two$$ kittens of the same color)?
